review.title: A Novel Online Real-time Classifier for Multi-label Data Streams
review.abstract: In this paper, a novel extreme learning machine based online multi-label classifier for real-time data streams is proposed. Multi-label classification is one of the actively researched machine learning paradigm that has gained much attention in the recent years due to its rapidly increasing real world applications. In contrast to traditional binary and multi-class classification, multi-label classification involves association of each of the input samples with a set of target labels simultaneously. There are no real-time online neural network based multi-label classifier available in the literature. In this paper, we exploit the inherent nature of high speed exhibited by the extreme learning machines to develop a novel online real-time classifier for multi-label data streams. The developed classifier is experimented with datasets from different application domains for consistency, performance and speed. The experimental studies show that the proposed method outperforms the existing state-of-the-art techniques in terms of speed and accuracy and can classify multi-label data streams in real-time.
histories: 8 pages, 7 tables, 3 figures. arXiv admin note: text overlap witharXiv:1609.00086

sections.heading: A. Performance Metrics
sections.text: The complexity of multi-label problems leads to a unique feature of multi-label classifiers, the so-called partial correctness of results. Since both the number of labels and the label identities must be predicted by the multi-label classifier, the problem of partial correctness arises. The classifier can incorrectly predict either the number of labels corresponding to an input sample or the identity of the corresponding target labels. Therefore, the hammer loss measurement is used to quantify the performance of the classifier, longitudinally with accuracy, precision, recall and formula 1. Hammer loss is calculated as a fraction of false labels to the total number of labels. Hammer loss for an ideal classifier is zero. Training time and testing time of the proposed technology are also evaluated and compared with the state of the art.

sections.heading: B. Consistency
sections.text: Since the initial weights of the networks were randomly selected for an ELM-based technique, the evaluation of the consistency is crucial. Therefore, the proposed technique is evaluated for consistency by means of 5-fold and 10-fold cross-validation.

sections.heading: C. Streaming Data Classification
sections.text: The proposed OSML-ELM technique is a real-time online multi-label classifier for streaming data applications. The performance of the proposed method will be based on five sets of data in different areas with a wide range of LC and LD. The results show that the proposed method is consistent and exceeds existing state-of-the-art techniques in terms of speed and remains one of the top methods in terms of performance. The high-speed nature of the OSML-ELM supports the scalability of the proposed technique for real-time data streams.

Due to the omnipresence of multi-label problems in a wide range of real world scenarios, multi-label classification is an emerging field in machine learning classification [15].
When compared to single label classification, multi-label classification is more difficult and more complex due to the increased generality of the multi-label problems [16].

Online learning is a family of machine learning techniques in which the learning is achieved by incrementally updating the system parameters from the data that arrives sequentially using single-pass learning procedure [17, 18].

Online learning is a family of machine learning techniques in which the learning is achieved by incrementally updating the system parameters from the data that arrives sequentially using single-pass learning procedure [17, 18].
Therefore, online learning techniques are preferred over batch learning techniques for real world applications [19, 20].
Therefore, online learning techniques are preferred over batch learning techniques for real world applications [19, 20].
It is to be noted that there is very limited research on multilabel classification for streaming data applications [21].

Sorower [22] defines multi-label classification as, “Given a training set, S = (xi, yi), 1 ≤ i ≤ n, consisting of n training instances, (xi ε X, yi ε Y) drawn from an unknown distribution D, the goal of multi-label learning is to produce a multi-label classifier h:X→Y that optimizes some specific evaluation function or loss function”.

al [23] categorized the existing batch learning based multilabel classification algorithm available in literature into two categories: Problem Transformation (PT) methods and Algorithm Adaptation (AA) methods.
al [24] extended the classification to include Ensemble (EN) based multi-label classification methods.
There are limited number of techniques available in the literature on multi-label classification for data streams [21].
The first work on multi-label classifier for data streams is based on ensemble of classifiers which are trained on successive data chunks [25].
al [26] proposes multi-label stream classification by extending the heoffding tree [27] by using batch multi-label classifier in each node.
al [26] proposes multi-label stream classification by extending the heoffding tree [27] by using batch multi-label classifier in each node.
Spyromitros-Xioufis [28] proposes binary relevance and kNN based multi-label classifier for data streams.

Microsoft [29] developed an Active Learning framework for multi-label classification as the result of the increase in demand for the need of multi-label classification in real world multimedia datasets.
al [30] for multi-label classification.
al [31] for online multi-label classification.

metadata.abstractText: In this paper, a novel extreme learning machine based online multi-label classifier for real-time data streams is proposed. Multi-label classification is one of the actively researched machine learning paradigm that has gained much attention in the recent years due to its rapidly increasing real world applications. In contrast to traditional binary and multiclass classification, multi-label classification involves association of each of the input samples with a set of target labels simultaneously. There are no real-time online neural network based multi-label classifier available in the literature. In this paper, we exploit the inherent nature of high speed exhibited by the extreme learning machines to develop a novel online realtime classifier for multi-label data streams. The developed classifier is experimented with datasets from different application domains for consistency, performance and speed. The experimental studies show that the proposed method outperforms the existing state-of-the-art techniques in terms of speed and accuracy and can classify multi-label data streams in real-time. Keywords—Real-time, Classification, Multi-label, Online, Extreme learning machines, High speed.
